awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Biomedical Materials, Devices, Therapeutics, and Emerging Frontiers
awd_abstract_narration:
This Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site at Rowan University funds student development and the advancement of interdisciplinary biomedical engineering and science research focusing on biomedical materials, devices, therapeutics, and emerging frontiers. The Site will provide opportunities for ten, diverse undergraduate participants each summer to conduct novel, cutting-edge research under the direction of faculty mentors from three colleges - the Henry M. Rowan College of Engineering, the College of Science and Mathematics, and Rowan's Cooper School of Medicine - and eight academic departments, with the Department of Biomedical Engineering as the lead. Students will participate as a group in weekly seminars and workshops that provide comprehensive professional development and allow cross-cultivation of the individual research experience. This REU Site will advance the field and prepare students for future advanced careers in engineering and science relevant to medicine and healthcare and provide a holistic experience for development of strong research skills. Enhancing or improving quality of life and health benefits society and is a cross-cutting theme in the National Academy of Engineering's Grand Challenges for Engineering in the 21st Century.

The goal of this REU Site is to provide undergraduates an exciting research experience that will prepare and motivate them for further education and careers in science and engineering as well as advance and support novel biomedical engineering and science research. The REU Site cohort will be a diverse group of undergraduate participants from four-year institutions and community colleges that have limited opportunity to engage in research activities. This REU site will be beneficial to the students' appreciation of interconnected and multi-disciplinary topics within the fields of science and engineering, understanding of related concepts between inter-related disciplines, presentation and problem solving skills, appreciation for life-long learning, and desire to pursue advanced studies and careers in science and engineering. Research projects will advance the field and be interdisciplinary in nature and will include biomaterials and tissue engineering, micro/nano systems and device development, regenerative medicine, biomolecule detection, medication development and evaluation, nanoparticle synthesis and development, and personalized medicine. Undergraduate and graduate student mentors from Rowan University will participate in the program and provide peer contacts.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
The REU site at Rowan University targeted a diverse group of undergraduate participants from four-year institutions and community colleges that otherwise had limited opportunity to engage in research activities and/or were underrepresented in science and engineering. We count 34 mentored undergraduate alumni from across the country. The program involved seventeen faculty mentors at Rowan from nine different science and engineering disciplines within an interdisciplinary focus spanning three different colleges (College of Engineering, College of Sciences and Mathematics, School of Medicine). Providing undergraduate students with research experience directly led to an increase in student perseverance in higher education and a greater number of students pursuing bachelor and graduate degrees.  The Rowan University program trained, encouraged, and motivated the next generation of scientists and engineers toward advanced degrees and technical challenges. Close to 75% of the REU students from this program have entered graduate or professional school or intend to do so within the next 5 years.  Many have received national and regional awards. Their work also led to publishable research that has advanced scientific knowledge and discovery. The REU Site was interdisciplinary in nature and advanced knowledge across a broad range of scientific and engineering disciplines.

 

REU participants were paired with faculty mentors to work in their laboratories on research projects focused on biomedical materials, devices, therapeutics, and emerging frontiers. Students were introduced to skills such as literature searching and review, research design, laboratory research techniques, written and oral presentation, as well as working in a team environment. Students also participated as a group in weekly seminars and workshops that allowed cross cultivation of the individual research experience as well as professional development (e.g., research methods, transferring to a BS degree program, graduate school and the graduate school application process, technical writing, effective presentation skills, career preparation, ethics in science and engineering, patents and commercialization). Social events occurred during the program and participating students lived together close to campus. This program created individuals who not only conducted better science but had a better understanding of science and engineering and its impact in the world. This program trained future technology leaders and created a more technically advanced and diverse workforce to increase our country?s global competiveness. The REU participants also shared these experiences with their friends and family making better informed citizens outside the boundaries of science, engineering, and the academic world.

 


Last Modified: 07/17/2023
Modified by: Mary M Staehle
